heading: 1.8.1 Objects
text: large part coding involve creating manipulating objects. Objects contain stuff. stuff can numbers, words, result operations analyses. assign content object using <-.Run following code console, change values name, age birthday details (birthday date next birthday). Press enter type line.see four objects now appear environment pane:name character (text) data. order R recognise text, must enclosed double quotation marks " ".age numeric data. order R recognise number, must enclosed quotation marks. Every year update age book confronted mortality getting ever closer.today stores result function Sys.Date(). function returns computer system's date. Unlike name age, hard-coded (.e., always return values enter), contents object today change dynamically date. , run function tomorrow, update date tomorrow's date.birthday also date hard-coded specific date. wrapped within .Date() function tells R interpret character string provide date rather text.print contents object, type object's name console press enter. Try printing four objects now.
code:
name <- "Emily"
age <- 38
today <- Sys.Date()
birthday <- as.Date("2024-07-11")

heading: 2.3 Activity 1: The Stroop Effect
text: chapter next chapter, going develop data skills using data one famous experiments psychology: Stroop Effect.First, taken part online version Stroop test. takes minutes complete. need device keyboard.Second, read Wikipedia summary Stroop Effect used psychological research.Finally, answer following questions. Please note responses save browser - want save , make note somewhere.Stroop Effect primarily measure?Color perceptionLanguage comprehensionCognitive interferenceReading speedThe Stroop Effect primarily measures cognitive interference, occurs processing specific stimulus feature impedes simultaneous processing second stimulus attribute.one possible explanation Stroop Effect?People naturally slower reading identifying colorsReading automatic process can interfere color identificationColor identification automatic process can interfere readingNone aboveThe Stroop Effect often explained theory automaticity, suggests reading—task recognizing words—become automatic process individuals, automatic reading process interferes task naming color.typical Stroop test,  trials (color ink matches word) completed faster  trials (color ink match word).Answer: congruent, incongruentIn typical Stroop test, two types tasks - congruent incongruent.Congruent tasks color ink matches word. example, word "BLUE" printed blue ink. case, visual color semantic information (meaning word) align "congruent."Incongruent tasks, hand, color ink match word. example, word "BLUE" might printed red ink. , visual color semantic information conflict "incongruent."Participants Stroop test typically asked name color ink, word. interference comes . Reading words automatic process literate adults participant's brain automatically reads word recognizing color ink. causes delay response time incongruent tasks, brain overcome initial automatic response read word.Therefore, congruent tasks typically completed faster incongruent tasks Stroop test. difference response times measure Stroop effect, demonstrates nature cognitive interference automatic process reading.

heading: 2.8.2 Function Help
text: want information function use , can look help document. function base R package loaded, can type ?function_name console access help file. top help give function package name.package loaded, use ?package_name::function_name. sure package function , use shortcut ??function_name give list possible options.console, type run code different help options . reason run help code console code chunk generally want save code script.Function help always organised way. example, look help ?beepr::beep. top, tells name function package curly brackets, short description function, followed longer description. Usage section shows function arguments. arguments default values, shown like function(arg = default). Arguments section lists argument explanation. may Details section even detail functions. Examples section last, shows examples can run console window see function works.Use help documentation find answers questions:first argument mean function? trimna.rmmeanxWhat package read_excel ? readrreadxlbasestats
code:
# get help with a package
?beepr

# get help with a function if the package it's from is already loaded
?beep

# get help with a function whether or not the package is loaded
?beepr::beep

# shows a list of potentially matching functions
??beep

Whenever read data R always initial check see data looks like expected. several ways can , try see results differ.environment pane, click dat ppt_info. open data give spreadsheet-like view (although edit like Excel).environment pane, click small blue play button left dat ppt_info. show structure object information including names variables object type .code chunk 5, write run summary(ppt_info) (dat)code chunk 5, write run str(ppt_info) (dat)median congruent reaction time 1 decimal place? mean incongruent reaction time 1 decimal place?

heading: 2.11 Activity 7: Visualise the data
text: going learn course, data visualisation extremely important. Visualisations can used give information dataset, can also used mislead.going look write code produce simple visualisations weeks, now, want focus read interpret different kinds graphs. Please feel free play around code change TRUE FALSE adjust values labels see happens worry understanding code. Just copy paste .Copy, paste run code code chunk 6 produce bar graph shows number men, women, non-binary participants dataset.men, women, non-binary participants sample? menMore womenMore non-binary participantsCopy, paste, run code code chunk 7 create violin-boxplots happiness scores income group.violin (wavy line) shows density. Basically, fatter wavy shape, data points point. called violin plot often looks (kinda) like violin.boxplot box middle. black line shows median score group. median calculated arranging scores order smallest largest selecting middle score.lines boxplot show interquartile range. really good explanation read boxplot .condition longest median reaction time? CongruentIncongruent
code:
ggplot(ppt_info, # data we're using
       aes(x = gender, # variable we want to show as bars
                     fill = gender)) + # make bars different colours
  geom_bar(show.legend = FALSE) + # add bar plot & turn off redundant legend
  scale_x_discrete(name = "Gender") + # edit x-axis label
  scale_fill_viridis_d(option = "D") + # colour-blind friendly
  scale_y_continuous(name = "Number of participants")+ # edit y-axis label
  theme_minimal() # add a theme
# create long-form data
dat_long <- pivot_longer(dat, 
                         cols = congruent_time:incongruent_time, 
                         names_to = "condition", 
                         values_to = "reaction_time")
# make plot
ggplot(dat_long, # data we're using
       aes(x = condition, # grouping variable (IV)
                     y = reaction_time, # measurement (DV)
                     fill = condition)) + # make bars different colours
  geom_violin(show.legend = FALSE, # turn off redundant legend for colour
              alpha = .4) + # make violin a bit transparent
  geom_boxplot(width = .2, # adjust size of boxplot
               show.legend = FALSE, # turn off redundant legend for colour
               alpha = .7)+ # make boxplots a little transparent
  scale_x_discrete(name = "Condition", # edit x-axis labels
                   labels = c("Congruent", "Incongruent")) +
  scale_y_continuous(name = "Reaction time (ms)") + # edit y-axis labels
  theme_minimal() + # add a theme
  scale_fill_viridis_d(option = "E") # colour-blind friendly colours
